metadata.title: Non-local analysis of free vibration of bi-directional functionally graded Euler-Bernoulli nano-beams

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
International Journal of Engineering Science
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/ijengsci
Non-local analysis of free vibration of bi-directional
functionally graded Euler–Bernoulli nano-beams
Mohammad Zamani Nejad a , ∗, Amin Hadi b
a Mechanical Engineering Department, Yasouj University, P. O. Box: 75914-353, Yasouj, Iran b Mechanical Engineering Faculty, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran
a r t i c l e i n f o
Article history: Received 12 April 2016 Revised 18 April 2016 Accepted 24 April 2016
Keywords: Free vibration Non-local elasticity theory Size effect Euler–Bernoulli nano-beams Bi-directional functionally graded materials (BDFGMs) Generalized differential quadrature method (GDQM)
a b s t r a c t
In this paper, the free vibration analysis of Euler–Bernoulli nano-beams made of bidirectional functionally graded material (BDFGM) with small scale effects is investigated. To study the small scale effects on free vibration, the non-local elasticity theory is applied. To the best of the researchers’ knowledge, in the literature, there is no study carried out into non-local elasticity theory for free vibration analysis of BDFGM nanostructures with arbitrary functions. The novelty of the present work is that it seeks to investigate size effects on free vibration analysis of bi-directional functionally graded (BDFG) Euler– Bernoulli nano-beams based on Eringen’s non-local elasticity theory. The material properties obey the arbitrary function in thickness and length direction. The governing equations are obtained, using the concept of Hamilton principle. Generalized differential quadrature method (GDQM) is used to solve the governing equations for various boundary conditions to obtain the natural frequencies of FG nano-beam. These models can degenerate into the classical models if the material length scale parameter is taken to be zero. Finally, some numerical results are presented to study the effects of material length scale parameter and inhomogeneity constant on free vibration analysis of FGM Euler–Bernoulli nano-beams.
© 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nanoscience is the study of phenomena and the manipulation of material at the atomic, molecular, and macromolecular scale, where the properties differ notably from the properties at a bigger scale. The nanotechnologies are the design, characterization, production and implementation of structures, mechanisms and systems by monitoring shape and size at the nanometric scale ( Wautelet, 2009 ). Recently, nanostructural elements such as nano-beams, nano-membranes and nano-plates have attracted worldwide attention from the research community thanks to their superior properties and extensive applications in nano-electro-mechanical (NEM) devices. At nanometer scales, size effects often become important ( Gopalakrishnan & Narendar, 2013 ). Both experimental and Molecular dynamics simulation results have invariably shown that the small-scale effects in the analysis of mechanical properties of nanostructures cannot be neglected and that classical continuum theories cannot be applied. Molecular dynamics simulation is a convenient method to simulate the mechanical behavior of small size structures. However, it is computationally expensive for structures with large numbers of atoms ( Gopalakrishnan & Narendar, 2013 ). In recent decades, several nonclassical continuum theories that contain additional material length scale have been developed to overcome this barrier. Among the size dependent continuum theories, the theory
∗ Corresponding author. Fax: + 98 7433221711. E-mail address: m_zamani@yu.ac.ir , m.zamani.n@gmail.com (M.Z. Nejad).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ijengsci.2016.04.011 0020-7225/© 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
of non-local continuum mechanics initiated by Eringen and coworkers ( Eringen, 1972a, 1972b, 1983, 2002 ) has been widely used to analyze many problems, such as wave propagation, dislocation, and crack singularities and the pioneer work of Peddieson, Buchanan, and McNitt (2003) has been used to solve problems involving nanostructures. Thus, the non-local theory of elasticity has been used to address the behavior of beams ( Aranda-Ruiz, Loya, & Fernández-Sáez, 2012; Loya, López-Puente, Zaera, & Fernández-Sáez, 2009; Lu, 2007; Phadikar & Pradhan, 2010; Reddy & El-Borgi, 2014 ), rods ( Murmu & Adhikari, 2010; Sun & Zhang, 2003 ) and plates ( Daneshmehr, Rajabpoor, & Hadi, 2015; Murmu & Pradhan, 2009; Natarajan, Chakraborty, Thangavel, Bordas, & Rabczuk, 2012; Zhou, Sheng, & Shen, 2014 ).
Functionally graded materials (FGMs) whose spatially varying properties are tailored to satisfy particular engineering applications have received considerable attention in recent years ( Zenkour, 2014 ). This continuously varying composition eliminates interface problems, and thus, the stress distributions are smooth ( Nejad & Fatehi, 2015 ). A number of papers considering various aspects of FGM have been published in recent years ( Ben-Oumrane et al., 2009; Kahrobaiyan, Rahaeifard, Tajalli, & Ahmadian, 2012; Mazarei, Nejad, & Hadi, 2016; Nejad, Rastgoo, & Hadi, 2014; Nejad, Rastgoo, & Hadi, 2014; Petrova & Schmauder, 2012; Radman, Huang, & Xie, 2014; Ş im ̧s ek & Reddy, 2013; Xue & Pan, 2013; Ziegler & Kraft, 2014 ).
Thanks to the advances in technology, FGMs have started to find their ways into micro-nano-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS/NEMS), for example in the form of shape memory alloy thin films with a global thickness in micro- or nano-scale ( Lü, Lim, & Chen, 2009b ), electrically actuated MEMS devices ( Zhang & Fu, 2012 ), and atomic force microscopes (AFMs) ( Kahrobaiyan, Asghari, Rahaeifard, & Ahmadian, 2010 ). It should be noted that most of the above-mentioned analyses are related to FGMs with material properties varying in one direction only. However, there are practical occasions which require tailored grading of macroscopic properties in two or even three directions. As reported by Steinberg (1986) , the fuselage of an aerospace craft undergoes an extremely high temperature field with excessive temperature gradient on the surface and through the thickness, when the plane sustains flight at a speed of Mach 8 and at an altitude of 29 km.
In this circumstance, the conventional unidirectional FGMs may not be so appropriate to resist multi-directional severe variations of temperature. Therefore, it is of great significance to develop novel FGMs with macroscopic properties varying in two or three directions (2D or 3D FGMs) to withstand a more general temperature field. The number of studies on beams and plates made of two-directional functionally graded material (2D-FGM) is still very limited. Lü, Lim, and Chen (2009a) proposed the state-space based differential quadrature method for the thermo-elastic analysis of bi-directional FGM plates. In addition, dynamic behavior of multi-directional FGM annular plates was investigated by Nie and Zhong (2010) . Zhao, Chen, and Lü (2012) , suggested a symplectic framework for the analysis of plane problems of BDFGMs in which the elastic modulus varies exponentially both along the longitudinal and transverse coordinates. The fully coupled thermomechanical behavior of BDFGMs beam structures, using isogeometric finite element model, was studied by Lezgy-Nazargah (2015) . Ş im ̧s ek (2015) , investigated free and forced vibration of BDFG Timoshenko beam under the action of a moving load. The material properties of the beam varied exponentially in both axial and thickness directions. Wang, Wang, Xu, Cheng, and Zeng (2016) studied the free vibration of a two-directional functionally graded beam which had variable material properties along the beam length and thickness. It is assumed that material properties vary through the length according to a simple power law distribution with an arbitrary power index and have an exponential gradation along the beam thickness. Li, Li, and Hu (2016) derived a size-dependent Timoshenko beam model which accounts for through-thickness power-law variation of a two-constituent functionally graded (FG) material, in the framework of the non-local strain gradient theory. Nejad, Hadi, and Rastgoo (2016) presented buckling analysis of arbitrary two-directional functionally graded Euler–Bernoulli nano-beams based on non-local elasticity theory.
To the best of the researchers’ knowledge, there are no studies carried out so far in the literature into bi-directional functionally graded Euler–Bernoulli nano-beams for free vibration analysis of nanostructures. Given this oversight, the aim of the present study is to investigate size effects on vibration analysis of BDFG Euler–Bernoulli nano-beams. To accomplish this, Eringen’s non-local theory is applied to study the small scale effects. The material properties of the beam vary as arbitrary function in both axial and thickness directions. At the end, size effect, non-local parameter and power index on natural frequency ratios are demonstrated with numerical results.

sections.heading: 2. Analysis
sections.text:
Consider a nano-beam of length L , width b , and thickness h made of functionally graded materials, as shown in Fig. 1 .
Cartesian coordinates ( x, y, z ) are considered.
The modulus of elasticity E and density ρ are assumed to vary as arbitrary functions in both axial and thickness directions, as indicated below
E = f 1 ( x ) g 1 ( z ) (1)
ρ = f 2 ( x ) g 2 ( z ) (2) where f 1 ( x ), f 2 ( x ), g 1 ( z ) and g 2 ( z ) are arbitrary functions.
Based on the Euler–Bernoulli beam theory, the axial displacement u and the transverse displacement of any point of the
beam, w , are given by { u = u 0 ( x ) − z ∂w ∂x
w = w ( x, t ) (3)
τ = e 0 ̄a /L is a material constant that depends on internal and external characteristic length (such as the lattice spacing and wavelength). The parameter e 0 is vital for the validity of non-local models. This parameter was determined by matching the dispersion curves based on atomistic models. σ nl is the non-local stress tensor at the reference point and σ l is the classical stress tensor at local point. In addition, the classical stress tensor is defined in the following way:
σ l = C : ε (14) Here C is the fourth order elasticity tensor and ‘:’ denotes the double dot product. Eringen numerically determined the functional form of the kernel. By choosing the appropriate kernel function, Eringen showed that the non-local constitutive equation given in integral form can be represented in an equivalent differential form as ( 1 − μ∇ 2 )σ nl = C : ε, μ = ( e 0 a ) 2 (15)

sections.heading: 3. Generalized differential quadrature method
sections.text:
In the case of the general boundary conditions, the analytical solution of Eq. (31) is difficult to obtain, so a GDQ approach is adopted for the solution of Eq. (31) . The GDQ approach may be an easy and useful tool for the purpose of analyzing more complex problems. In addition, GDQM is an efficient numerical method for the solution of differential equations. It is assumed that the grid points are located on the zeros of the Chebyshev polynomials ( Shu & Chew, 1998 ) and to discretize the solution domain, one can assume a set of N grid points in the x-direction as
X i = L
2
{ 1 − cos ( i − 1 N − 1 ) π } , i = 1 , . . . , N − 1 (32)
In this method, the derivatives of a function f ( x ), at a point x i , are expressed as
f ( n ) x ( x i ) = N ∑
j=1 C ( n ) i j
f ( x j ) , n = 1 , . . . , N − 1 (33)
where N is the number of the grid points over the x direction. C (n ) i j is the respective weighting coefficient through the x direction obtained through the following equations.
For the first order derivative ( n = 1 )
C ( 1 ) i j = M ( X i ) ( X i − X j ) M ( X j ) , i, j = 1 , . . . , N j = i (34) where
M ( X i ) = N x ∏ j=1 j = i ( X i − X j ) (35)

In addition, coefficients A and B are matrices and their dimensions depend on the number of domain and boundary sample points. After eliminating boundary nodes X b including ( W ) in Eq. (39) by using the boundary conditions, the dimension of the coefficient matrices reduces. Finally, Eq. (39) can be rewritten to give an eigenvalue problem as
[ K ] [ X d ] = [ ω̄ ] [ I ] [ X d ] (40) Solving the obtained eigenvalue problem gives the natural frequency ( ̄ω ) of the FG Euler–Bernoulli nano-beams based on
non-local elasticity theory.

sections.heading: 4. Results and discussion
sections.text:
In this section, the free vibration of BDFG Euler–Bernoulli nano-beams based on non-local elasticity theory is investigated
by numerical results.
First, the verification of the free vibration of nano-beam solution when the isotropic beam is assumed will be performed in comparison with that of Eltaher, Alshorbagy, and Mahmoud (2013) . These authors present vibration analysis of Euler– Bernoulli nano-beams by using finite element method. Here, the beam’s geometric and material properties are given as follows:
Young’s modulus is 30 MPa, density is 1 kg/m 3 , width of the beam is 1 nm and the length of the beam is 10 nm. It can be seen from Table 1 that the dimensionless frequency in mode 1 of this paper can well agree with those obtained
using FEM. Frequency ratio and dimensionless frequency are defined as follows: ω̄ = ω L 2 √
m 0 I 2
(41)
Fr = Frequency ratio = ω̄ NL ω̄ L
(42)
n indicates a fully metallic beam. The variation of the combination of ceramic and metal is linear for n = 1 . According to Fig. 3 , in the same position (0 < x / L < 1), it is observed that for higher values of β , the stiffness increases.
Fig. 4 illustrates the convergence of the GDQM in obtaining the non-dimensional-frequency. It is observed that considering more than 8 sample points does not affect the accuracy of the results significantly. In this
figure, the non-dimensional-frequency error is defined as e = ∣∣∣∣ ω̄ N+1 − ω̄ N ω̄ N ∣∣∣∣ × 100 (45) where e is a small value number and in this analysis, it is taken to be 10 −2 .
Frequency ratio changes in accordance to the length of the beam are shown in Fig. 5 for a h = 1 nm, β = 0 and n 1 = n 2 = 2 for various non-local parameters. Frequency ratio increases for all non-local parameters by increasing the length of the beam. In addition, this figure demonstrates that as the length of the beam increases, the frequency ratio approaches the local elasticity solution for considerably large beam length. Moreover, from this, it can be observed that as the non-local parameter increases, the frequency ratio decreases. Therefore, the nano-beam becomes more size dependent, irrespective of the beam dimensions. Fig. 6 shows the dimensionless frequency of the nano-beam against the size scale parameter in different modes. This figure shows that in different modes, with increases in size scale parameter, the dimensionless frequency decreases.
Given that n 1 = n 2 = n , dimensionless natural frequency for the first five modes against n is shown in Fig. 7 . It is apparent from the curve that there is an increase in the value of dimensionless natural frequency as n increases. Fig. 8 illustrates the dimensionless natural frequency against β for the first mode. This figure shows that as β increases, the dimensionless natural frequency increases too. Besides, this figure shows that for higher values of β , stiffness increases.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, free vibration analysis of FG Euler–Bernoulli nano-beam based on non-local elasticity is presented. The FG nano-beam is assumed to be graded through thickness and length directions, following the arbitrary material distribution. The governing equations and the boundary conditions are derived, using the Hamilton principle. Afterwards, GDQM is applied to solve the governing equations to obtain the natural frequencies of FG nano-beam. Comparison of the results obtained from GDQM with those obtained from Eltaher et al. (2013) solution proved the efficiency and accuracy of the method adopted in the present study. Finally, some numerical results are presented to compare the results of the proposed model with those predicted by Classical theory. It is also shown that small scale effects significantly contribute to the mechanical behavior of FG nano-beam, a significant fact which cannot be neglected. Further, frequency ratio decreases with the increase in the size scale parameter value. The results presented in this work may provide useful guidelines for designing and developing FG nano-beams based on nano devices that make use of the vibration properties of FG nano-beam. To show the effect of inhomogeneity on the vibration properties of FG nano-beam, different values were considered for material inhomogeneity parameters n and β . The presented results show that the material inhomogeneity has a significant influence on the mechanical behaviors of the BDFG Euler–Bernoulli nano-beams.

In this circumstance, the conventional unidirectional FGMs may not be so appropriate to resist multi-directional severe variations of temperature. Therefore, it is of great significance to develop novel FGMs with macroscopic properties varying in two or three directions (2D or 3D FGMs) to withstand a more general temperature field. The number of studies on beams and plates made of two-directional functionally graded material (2D-FGM) is still very limited. Lü, Lim, and Chen (2009a) proposed the state-space based differential quadrature method for the thermo-elastic analysis of bi-directional FGM plates.

of non-local continuum mechanics initiated by Eringen and coworkers ( Eringen, 1972a, 1972b, 1983, 2002 ) has been widely used to analyze many problems, such as wave propagation, dislocation, and crack singularities and the pioneer work of Peddieson, Buchanan, and McNitt (2003) has been used to solve problems involving nanostructures. Thus, the non-local theory of elasticity has been used to address the behavior of beams ( Aranda-Ruiz, Loya, & Fernández-Sáez, 2012; Loya, López-Puente, Zaera, & Fernández-Sáez, 2009; Lu, 2007; Phadikar & Pradhan, 2010; Reddy & El-Borgi, 2014 ), rods ( Murmu & Adhikari, 2010; Sun & Zhang, 2003 ) and plates ( Daneshmehr, Rajabpoor, & Hadi, 2015; Murmu & Pradhan, 2009; Natarajan, Chakraborty, Thangavel, Bordas, & Rabczuk, 2012; Zhou, Sheng, & Shen, 2014 ). Functionally graded materials (FGMs) whose spatially varying properties are tailored to satisfy particular engineering applications have received considerable attention in recent years ( Zenkour, 2014 ). This continuously varying composition eliminates interface problems, and thus, the stress distributions are smooth ( Nejad & Fatehi, 2015 ). A number of papers considering various aspects of FGM have been published in recent years ( Ben-Oumrane et al., 2009; Kahrobaiyan, Rahaeifard, Tajalli, & Ahmadian, 2012; Mazarei, Nejad, & Hadi, 2016; Nejad, Rastgoo, & Hadi, 2014; Nejad, Rastgoo, & Hadi, 2014; Petrova & Schmauder, 2012; Radman, Huang, & Xie, 2014; Ş im ̧s ek & Reddy, 2013; Xue & Pan, 2013; Ziegler & Kraft, 2014 ). Thanks to the advances in technology, FGMs have started to find their ways into micro-nano-electro-mechanical systems (MEMS/NEMS), for example in the form of shape memory alloy thin films with a global thickness in micro- or nano-scale ( Lü, Lim, & Chen, 2009b ), electrically actuated MEMS devices ( Zhang & Fu, 2012 ), and atomic force microscopes (AFMs) ( Kahrobaiyan, Asghari, Rahaeifard, & Ahmadian, 2010 ). It should be noted that most of the above-mentioned analyses are related to FGMs with material properties varying in one direction only. However, there are practical occasions which require tailored grading of macroscopic properties in two or even three directions. As reported by Steinberg (1986) , the fuselage of an aerospace craft undergoes an extremely high temperature field with excessive temperature gradient on the surface and through the thickness, when the plane sustains flight at a speed of Mach 8 and at an altitude of 29 km. In this circumstance, the conventional unidirectional FGMs may not be so appropriate to resist multi-directional severe variations of temperature. Therefore, it is of great significance to develop novel FGMs with macroscopic properties varying in two or three directions (2D or 3D FGMs) to withstand a more general temperature field. The number of studies on beams and plates made of two-directional functionally graded material (2D-FGM) is still very limited. Lü, Lim, and Chen (2009a) proposed the state-space based differential quadrature method for the thermo-elastic analysis of bi-directional FGM plates. In addition, dynamic behavior of multi-directional FGM annular plates was investigated by Nie and Zhong (2010) .

It should be noted that most of the above-mentioned analyses are related to FGMs with material properties varying in one direction only. However, there are practical occasions which require tailored grading of macroscopic properties in two or even three directions. As reported by Steinberg (1986) , the fuselage of an aerospace craft undergoes an extremely high temperature field with excessive temperature gradient on the surface and through the thickness, when the plane sustains flight at a speed of Mach 8 and at an altitude of 29 km. Therefore, it is of great significance to develop novel FGMs with macroscopic properties varying in two or three directions (2D or 3D FGMs) to withstand a more general temperature field. The number of studies on beams and plates made of two-directional functionally graded material (2D-FGM) is still very limited. Lü, Lim, and Chen (2009a) proposed the state-space based differential quadrature method for the thermo-elastic analysis of bi-directional FGM plates. In addition, dynamic behavior of multi-directional FGM annular plates was investigated by Nie and Zhong (2010) . Zhao, Chen, and Lü (2012) , suggested a symplectic framework for the analysis of plane problems of BDFGMs in which the elastic modulus varies exponentially both along the longitudinal and transverse coordinates.

Lü, Lim, and Chen (2009a) proposed the state-space based differential quadrature method for the thermo-elastic analysis of bi-directional FGM plates. In addition, dynamic behavior of multi-directional FGM annular plates was investigated by Nie and Zhong (2010) . Zhao, Chen, and Lü (2012) , suggested a symplectic framework for the analysis of plane problems of BDFGMs in which the elastic modulus varies exponentially both along the longitudinal and transverse coordinates. The fully coupled thermomechanical behavior of BDFGMs beam structures, using isogeometric finite element model, was studied by Lezgy-Nazargah (2015) .

of non-local continuum mechanics initiated by Eringen and coworkers ( Eringen, 1972a, 1972b, 1983, 2002 ) has been widely used to analyze many problems, such as wave propagation, dislocation, and crack singularities and the pioneer work of Peddieson, Buchanan, and McNitt (2003) has been used to solve problems involving nanostructures. A number of papers considering various aspects of FGM have been published in recent years ( Ben-Oumrane et al., 2009; Kahrobaiyan, Rahaeifard, Tajalli, & Ahmadian, 2012; Mazarei, Nejad, & Hadi, 2016; Nejad, Rastgoo, & Hadi, 2014; Nejad, Rastgoo, & Hadi, 2014; Petrova & Schmauder, 2012; Radman, Huang, & Xie, 2014; Ş im ̧s ek & Reddy, 2013; Xue & Pan, 2013; Ziegler & Kraft, 2014 ). Lü, Lim, and Chen (2009a) proposed the state-space based differential quadrature method for the thermo-elastic analysis of bi-directional FGM plates. In addition, dynamic behavior of multi-directional FGM annular plates was investigated by Nie and Zhong (2010) . Zhao, Chen, and Lü (2012) , suggested a symplectic framework for the analysis of plane problems of BDFGMs in which the elastic modulus varies exponentially both along the longitudinal and transverse coordinates. The fully coupled thermomechanical behavior of BDFGMs beam structures, using isogeometric finite element model, was studied by Lezgy-Nazargah (2015) . Ş im ̧s ek (2015) , investigated free and forced vibration of BDFG Timoshenko beam under the action of a moving load. The material properties of the beam varied exponentially in both axial and thickness directions. Wang, Wang, Xu, Cheng, and Zeng (2016) studied the free vibration of a two-directional functionally graded beam which had variable material properties along the beam length and thickness. It is assumed that material properties vary through the length according to a simple power law distribution with an arbitrary power index and have an exponential gradation along the beam thickness. Li, Li, and Hu (2016) derived a size-dependent Timoshenko beam model which accounts for through-thickness power-law variation of a two-constituent functionally graded (FG) material, in the framework of the non-local strain gradient theory.

Lü, Lim, and Chen (2009a) proposed the state-space based differential quadrature method for the thermo-elastic analysis of bi-directional FGM plates. In addition, dynamic behavior of multi-directional FGM annular plates was investigated by Nie and Zhong (2010) . Zhao, Chen, and Lü (2012) , suggested a symplectic framework for the analysis of plane problems of BDFGMs in which the elastic modulus varies exponentially both along the longitudinal and transverse coordinates. Ş im ̧s ek (2015) , investigated free and forced vibration of BDFG Timoshenko beam under the action of a moving load. Nejad, Hadi, and Rastgoo (2016) presented buckling analysis of arbitrary two-directional functionally graded Euler–Bernoulli nano-beams based on non-local elasticity theory.
Table 1 Comparison of non-dimensional-frequency in mode 1 for a clamped-clamped nano-beam with Eltaher et al. (2013).
Comparison of the results obtained from GDQM with those obtained from Eltaher et al. (2013) solution proved the efficiency and accuracy of the method adopted in the present study.

metadata.abstractText: In this paper, the free vibration analysis of Euler–Bernoulli nano-beams made of bidirectional functionally graded material (BDFGM) with small scale effects is investigated. To study the small scale effects on free vibration, the non-local elasticity theory is applied. To the best of the researchers’ knowledge, in the literature, there is no study carried out into non-local elasticity theory for free vibration analysis of BDFGM nanostructures with arbitrary functions. The novelty of the present work is that it seeks to investigate size effects on free vibration analysis of bi-directional functionally graded (BDFG) Euler– Bernoulli nano-beams based on Eringen’s non-local elasticity theory. The material properties obey the arbitrary function in thickness and length direction. The governing equations are obtained, using the concept of Hamilton principle. Generalized differential quadrature method (GDQM) is used to solve the governing equations for various boundary conditions to obtain the natural frequencies of FG nano-beam. These models can degenerate into the classical models if the material length scale parameter is taken to be zero. Finally, some numerical results are presented to study the effects of material length scale parameter and inhomogeneity constant on free vibration analysis of FGM Euler–Bernoulli nano-beams. © 2016 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
